bibl.title: Letter from [Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed] to Philip Showalter Hench, July 15, [1941]

div1.p: Reed is impressed with Hench's address on the Yellow Fever Commission presented in Cleveland. He discusses his interactions with the author Laura Wood Roper.

div1.head: Letter from [Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed] to Philip Showalter Hench, July 15, [1941]
div1.opener:
2810 THIRTY SIXTH PLACE
WASHINGTON, D. C.
July 15th
My dear Doctor Hench -
div1.p:
Upon my return from a
visit at Blue Ridge, where my sister
has been quite sick I received your
letter of July 1st.

I am grateful to you for your
letter and for the copy of the address
you gave at Cleveland.

My sister was deeply impressed
with all that took place on that
occassion and for the many countries
shown her by you and many others
at the meeting.

I saw her upon her return
and to way the least she was spell bound
and thrilled with all that occurred.
May I thank you for the many
courtesies shown her at that time.

I read your paper with much
interest and face that you handeled
admirably a difficult subject,
for it is not an easy task for
one to get the spirit, the back ground.
The difficulties and the atmosphere of an
event which transpired forty years ago.

Answering your question re-
Miss Wood - She asked me for an inter-
view and told me she was writing a
book on Walter Reed. I gladly gave
her such information as I could
but I am no way suggested that
you might have information she desired or that
she confer with you and I do not feel that I
have any right to suggest that you do & do not
make available to her any data you may have -
I told her Generals Kean - Ireland and Truby and Colonels
Philip Hungaylon and Siler knew my Father quite
well and might be able to give her information
as to his personalities and mannerisms - This was
one of the principle points she was endevoring
to obtain from me - I know nothing about her
or her literary ability.

Thanking you again for your letter
and interesting enclosure - Law
